Message.Msg: North Korea could reach U.S. with nuclear arms: Pentagon WASHINGTON - North Korea's continuing development of nuclear technology and long-range ballistic missiles will move it closer to its stated goal of being able to hit the United States with an atomic weapon, a new Pentagon report to Congress said on Thursday.

Message.Title: What good are low interest rates to a small business if you can't borrow FED?
Message.Msg: Do you folks not get what is happening out here on the fruited plain? Banks are so paranoid about loses they have virtually stop lending to small business and for mortgages. All the citizens money the FED put into the banking systems to bail them out is still in the banks which is just poker money for their proprietary trading rooms. Look don't lend to people of bad credit but "Sweet Jesus" how can you expand if you have a good business plan but can't get a loan. All banking is dead money to main street! Remember Mr. Banker, your greed to provide mortgage money to bad credit risks was all predicated on your ability to sell off those bad loans to unsuspecting investors! You created the crisis and are about to create another credit crisis!

Topic.Title: What good are low interest rates to a small business if you can't borrow FED?

Message.Msg: Also, If you don't have the Customers to buy or use you Product with the help you are getting now from the Gov't. Why would you even apply for a loan. I know, you are trying to keep your doors open till it gets better. Well with going on in DC now that's not going to happen in the next 4 years. They talk a good line, but: Were is the Beef? Were is the Money? Were is the Help for the Small Business as Promised? Were are the Loans?

Message.Title: European Commission on Friday cut its growth forecasts for the 17-nation euro area, saying it now expects gross domestic product will shrink 0.4% this year, versus prior expectations for a drop of 0.3%. Message.Title: This Stock is About to take off !!!
Message.Msg: Equities researchers at Needham & Company increased their target price on shares of FormFactor (NASDAQ: FORM) from $7.00 to $8.00 in a report issued on Thursday, StockRatingsNetwork reports. The firm currently has a “buy” rating on the stock. Shares of FormFactor (NASDAQ: FORM) traded down 4.03% during mid-day trading on Thursday, hitting $4.76. FormFactor has a one year low of $3.70 and a one year high of $6.92. The stock’s 50-day moving average is currently $4.7. The company’s market cap is $256.8 million. FormFactor (NASDAQ: FORM) last posted its quarterly earnings results on Wednesday, May 1st. The company reported ($0.13) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of ($0.18) by $0.05. The company had revenue of $52.60 million for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $51.68 million. During the same quarter in the prior year, the company posted ($0.29) earnings per share. The company’s quarterly revenue was up 51.1% on a year-over-year basis. Analysts expect that FormFactor will post $-0.33 EPS for the current fiscal year. FormFactor, Inc. (NASDAQ: FORM) designs, develops, manufactures, sells and supports precision semiconductor wafer probe cards.

Message.Title: South Carolina bill would make it a crime to implement ObamaCare
Message.Msg: The Supreme Court may have ruled ObamaCare is constitutional, but implementing the controversial federal law would become a crime in South Carolina if a bill passed by the state House becomes law. The bill, approved Wednesday by a vote of 65-39, declares President Obama's signature legislation "null and void." Whereas the law that Obama pushed and Congress passed is known as the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, South Carolina's law would be known as the Freedom of Health Care Protection Act. It would prohibit state officials and employees from "enforcing or attempting to enforce such unconstitutional laws" and "establish criminal penalties and civil liability" for those who engage in activities that aid the implementation of ObamaCare.

Topic.Title: South Carolina bill would make it a crime to implement ObamaCare

Message.Msg: Kind of anti-federal and I am glad some states stand up to federal control. The US federal government is an enormous inefficient beast.

Topic.Title: Obama: "I will continue to do everything in my power to pass common-sense reforms that keep guns out of the hands of criminals"

Message.Msg: Oh BS, population control by keeping guns out of the hands of people with criminal records and domestic violence charges or are insane? That is population control to you? Or is that just political expediency? While criminals may be able to beg, buy or borrow guns illegally even with background checks it will make it more difficult and they will have to be much more motivated than if they can just go to the gun show, join the IRA and get one no questions asked. My recommendation would be that any one who purchases a gun that is involved in a crime should bear some criminal liability. Weapons should be secured so that criminals and children can not obtain them. Reluctance to do so as in the case of the mother of the Sandy Hook shooter, should be criminal. No responsible gun owner should have made a weapon available to someone with his known mental instability. Who sold or provided the guns to the Boston bombers? Who sold guns to a non US citizen on an FBI watch lost?
